Forgive me for spamming multiple channels, I'm trying to get a handle for where I/we can best work/collaborate/publish/report on the no-theming-needed initiative I'm leading, and how much of that I should do.

The original mention of the initiative is in the forums:
https://forum.backdropcms.org/forum/official-initiative-theme-development-should-not-be-necessary-use-backdrop-cms

I've created a matching issue in Github:
https://github.com/backdrop/backdrop-issues/issues/4436

And now I'm creating a "topic" in Zulip :)

Copied from: https://forum.backdropcms.org/forum/official-initiative-theme-development-should-not-be-necessary-use-backdrop-cms Goal: People should be able to use backdrop without needing to know h...

I see a few logical branches coming up, but rather than create structure before it's required, for the moment I'll just dump everything into that one Github issue. While I anticipate later needing to split it up, I'll delay that until it gets to be too big for one issue, at which point we can factor it.

A great example I've found of a ready-to-wear theme is the Twenty Seventeen WordPress theme:

https://wordpress.org/themes/twentyseventeen/

Wordpress releases a new theme each calendar year; this was the one released in 2017. It includes relatively easy-to-use paralax elements, which still look cutting edge to me.

Twenty Seventeen
Twenty Seventeen brings your site to life with header video and immersive featured images. With a focus on business sites, it features multiple sections on the front page as well as widgets, navigation and social menus, a logo, and more. Personalize its asymmetrical grid with a custom color scheme and showcase your multimedia content with post formats. Our default theme for 2017 works great in many languages, for any abilities, and on any device.

I noted one particular challenge in providing ready-to-go themes for Backdrop: people will use different layouts, not necessarily the default ones.
Yep, that's why I tend to stick to custom themes for the site in question. Apparently all contrib themes should support all core layouts (not an easy feat).
Or, in the case of my experiment: the default layouts look different than the example which I'm trying to build.
That's the issue with trying to convert a third-party design to Backdrop. It requires a theme and layout to look the same. Otherwise themes are just colour schemes basically.
Yeah! So far I've also only build custom themes. But I guess it's time to accept the challenge!
The strategy could be: Make a theme look nice in all layouts, and recommend certain layouts for people who want the original third-party design.
Actually, some designs require also more detailed instructions to get the 'original' design, e.g. "don't put the Hero block in the Top but in the Content region".
However, so far really interesting, the experiment!
And sub-theming Basis (instead of making a stand-alone theme) works also well so far.

Next step is defining the problem space. What's a good sampling of themes? I've been pondering adjectives, as a way to figure it out:

  • dark/light
  • playful/businesslike
  • retro/modern/edgy/futuristic/minmalist
  • compact/open
  • flat/3D/Material Design/skeuomorphic
  • monochromatic/colorful
  • vibrant/muted
  • chunky/elegant
  • simple/elaborate
  • textured/shiny/glossy/fuzzy
  • Asian/African/Middle Eastern/teutonic
  • Avant-garde/brutalist/impressionist

Obviously we can't supply themes that hit each of these categories, or even a large portion of them, but I'd like to see some different options represented.

Ah, I would call that "steps for the initiative process." I answered the opposite branch.

Your list looks pretty good; I was envisioning something like this:

  1. Figure out what attributes differ between themes.
  2. Find examples of existing themes across all platforms that exhibit different attributes
  3. Look for low-hanging fruit. Existing Backdrop themes? D7 themes? Wordpress Themes? HTML or other environments?
  4. Of the non-low-hanging fruit, which conversions seem to be plausible?
  5. What mechanisms do we want to provide to demo themes? Sample content? Suggested layouts? Tugboat?
  6. How do we test the themes?
  7. Maintenance. Once the MPV is released, how do we keep it from getting stale? How do we maintain the themes, add to them, retire them?
  8. How do we want to package and "market" the results?

That's by no means a final or definitive list, it's just meant as a starting point.

Figure out what attributes differ between themes

Could you clarify what this means please?
And I think we need a checklist on the issue queue and some sub-issues so that we can get people discussing and starting on these.

I'm just listening to the dev meeting (first time I've listed to a meeting in a while) and towards the end you're talking about why Tugboat takes longer now than before to spin up a demo site. I think one of the reasons is that previously it would start a job to build a preview site, then wait 3 seconds and check if the job was complete, otherwise repeat. Now however, Tugboat provides a 'Retry-After' header which specifies how long you should wait before trying again. It's currently (or was when I was doing all this a few months ago) set to 10 seconds. I asked the Tugboat guys about this and while they admitted it was a long time to wait (for something that should be fairly quick), they also said that ignoring this 'retry-after' time would technically be hacking their API and advised against it. So that's why it takes longer. Solutions would be to hack their API and ignore this time (just continually check the job status every 2-3 seconds (instead of 10), or ask @quicksketch to talk to them and see if it's possible they reduce that 10 second wait time...

For reference: https://github.com/backdrop-contrib/tugboat/blob/1.x-1.x/tugboat.pages.inc#L67

But anyway, I want to step back from implementation a bit and record what's on my mind. I think I see the path to complete R2W. I'll lay out an outline right here, right now, and then (if there aren't objections) move it to the forum thread, incorporating improvements suggested here. I apologize if this causes your computer or phone to beep a lot, it should be all done within a half hour or so.

My impression is that it's already possible to create a good-looking site without needing custom code; it's just not obvious how to do it. So that reduces R2W to two distinct steps:
1) Document how to create a good-looking site without coding.
2) See which parts of that process can be optimized and streamlined

Step 1 includes:

  • Figuring out what you're trying to do
  • Selecting a theme (including finding, previewing, installing, and configuring)
  • Choosing/configuring/creating layouts
  • Color choices (and possibly other global visual configurations)
  • Modules/systems for things like carousels
  • Content creation (for example heroes/icons/backgrounds)
(Things missing from step 1?)

Step 2 might include:

  • Suggestions for resources to understand visual web design
  • Better previews of themes. Jen has already implemented improvements, but there are others we can. Specifically, I think we should have at least options for multiple preview pics, standard content, a way to view things that aren't just the front page, previews that aren't dependent on content, full-size and/or "live" previews, previews with your content, automated preview generation, etc.
  • Help with layouts. How hard is it to store and apply completed layouts?
  • Color options, storing and retrieving
  • Config scripts
  • content imports

...creating a separate content type for each theme.
